Meaning: <필요 없는 것 등>을 버리다, 처분하다, <사람>을 내쫓다
Example: We finally got rid of out spider problem, but now we have ants.
Note: to free oneself of; to throw out

Example: Are you sure you got the directions straight?
Harold got plastered at the wedding and fell into the wedding cake.
Jennifer has for men on the job painting her house.
Nicole lost her head after losing the elections and started yelling at all her friends.
Note: to lose control of one’s behavior; to not know what one is doing

Example: Let me level with you. I’m voting for Andrea instead of you.
Note: to speak openly and honestly with someone

Example: The investment bank let Chris go after they discovering he was stealing erasers, paper clips, and other office supplies.

Word: no use crying over spilt milk
Example: Nicole realized she’d made some mistakes with her campaign for president, but there was no use crying over spilt milk.
Note: there’s no point in regretting something that’s too late to change

Example: You want me to sit in that sauna for an hour? Not on your life!
Debbie is a doctor and her husband is a lawyer. They’re quite well off.
When her great aunt died, Anne inherited a small fortune.
Jenny told Nicole she would vote for her, but all along she was planning on voting for Andrea.
John is in charge of all international sales for his company.
I can’t remember the lyrics.
Ted is sick and tired of hearing about what an excellent student Nicole is
Ashley’s parents freaked out when she told them she was dropping out of college to become an actress.
Note: to respond to something irrationally or crazily; to overreact

Example: You want to work here at Lulu’s Dance Club? First things first, have you ever worked as a dancer before?
Note: let’s focus on the most important thing or task first

Example: Once the test is in progress, you will not be allowed to leave the room.
Note: happening; under way; going on now

Example: We’re not sure yet whether or not we want to buy the house. We’d better buy some time so we can think about it over the weekend.
Cut it out! Stop trying to pull my shoes off!
Note: stop it; stop the annoying behavior

Example: If you’re not all better, you shouldn’t go to work tomorrow.
Did people tease you when you were a kid?
90% of patients can be cured of the disease.
Adam made a fortune when he sold his company to Microsoft.
Note: to make a lot of money

Example: Chill out! If we miss this train, we’ll just take the next one.
If you want to break into journalism, it’s a good idea to work on a college newspaper.
Note: to enter or be let into a profession

Example: Before Tim left for Europe, his parents gave him $400 in spending money.
You paid last time we went to the movies. Let me foot the bill this time.
Donna wined and dined Bob and Susan and then presented them with a contract for the sale of Susan’s Scrumptious Cookies.
Note: to take someone out for an evening or an expensive meal

Example: In the world of women’s tennis, the Williams sisters are the cream of the crop.
Don’t ask for Susan’s advice on fashion. She’s really out of it. She wears sneakers with everything.
Note: not aware or knowledgeable about trends or modern habits

Example: The basketball team hasn’t lost a game all season. They’re on a winning streak!
You won five dollars in the lottery? Big deal!
Note: So what? That doesn’t really matter

Example: If you wrap up your homework by eight o’clock, we’ll have time to catch a movie tonight.

Meaning: In any way; to any extent
Example:
Are you hungry, at all?
Robin never really liked him at all.
One of the men grabbed Tom’s hair and yanked his head back.
Note: To pull something hard and suddenly, with a quick movement

Example: I used to earn more money when I worked at the bank, but I find teaching much more fulfilling.
Note: A feeling of utter (complete) happiness and satisfaction

Meaning: 누군가가 당신의 손님이라는것을 말하는 다른 방법
Example: It’s been a joy having you at my house this weekend.
Note: Another way to say that someone is your guest.

Meaning: This is another way of saying “you’re welcome” when someone tells you, “thanks”.
Used for giving your opinion when you think other people might not agree.
Example: We’ve been to more expensive hotels, but I’d say this is the one with the best service.
We didn’t deserve to win. 우리는 이길 자격이 없었다

Meaning: To do something or say something that’s different from what other people do or say.
If something moves you or is moving, it means that it causes you to feel strong emotions.
something that is stupid or completely untrue.
Another way to say that you are joking.
to change food that you have just eaten into substances that your body can use. to understand new information, especially when there is a lot of it or it is difficult to understand
Example: I struggled to digest the news.

Meaning: to lift someone or something to a higher position
Note: 수준, 지위등을 향상시키다. 사람을 승진시키다. elevate sb to sth, …을 …에 올려놓다.

Meaning: the total amount of money that person spends during a particular period of time (= income)
Example: Unnecessary expenditure of time and money

Meaning: not considering yourself or your ideas to be as important as other people’s
to increase in degree or strength, or to make something do this
to succeed in getting information or a reaction from someone, especially when this is difficult
Example: The test uses pictures to elicit words from the child.

Meaning: to risk money or possessions on the result of something such as a card game or a race, whey you do not know for certain what the result will be (=bet)
Example: We won $700 gambling in Las Vegas.

Meaning: the ability to behave in a calm controlled way even in a difficult situation
Example: The family faced their ordeal with dignity.
They are expected to launch a major offensive
The Romans invaded Britain 2000 years ago.
Are you threatening me?
Hi inspired many young people to take up the sport

Meaning: health는 질병이 없고 의학적으로 몸에 이상이 없는 상태, fitness는 한발 더 나가서 신체적활동에 문제가 없는 튼튼한 상태.

Example: At present we have no evidence of life on other planets.
Sales slumped by 20% last year
a high level of motivation
I don’t really know who she hangs out with.

Meaning: (삶∙직업 등에서) 성취감을 못 느끼는, 만족스럽지 못한
<숨겨져 있던 사실 등> 을 밝히다, 드러내다, 폭로하다
Example: The information was first revealed in a Sunday newspaper.

Meaning: <특정 활동 등> 을 계속 해나가다, <목적∙취미 등> 을 추구하다, <계획 등> 을 추진하다
Example: pursue a career
You can’t diffuse your energy, trying to do a little bit of everything, or you’ll always be in conflict with yourself.
disastrous floods

Meaning: 주의를 산만하게 하는 것, 집중을 방해하는 것
Example: I can’t work at home – there are too many distractions.
I find it difficult to wind down after a day at work.
She ignored his protests and walked away.
The toy didn’t engage her interest for long.
be immersed in something
an advantage  or profit that you get as a result of doing something

Meaning:
up: (사전∙콤퓨터 등에서) ⋯을 찾아보다
at: (문제점 등을 찾기 위해) ⋯을 살펴보다, 검사하다
on: (나서지 않고) 지켜보기만 하다
out: <오래전 물건 등>을 찾아놓다, 찾아보다

off: (<뻐스∙기차∙비행기 등>에서) 내리다, 퇴근하다
in: 차에 타다
on: 일이 되어가다, 일을 해나가다 (Let me know how you get on.)
up: (잠자리에서) 일어나다

Example: On the weekend, I sleep in until 11 AM.
I get up at 7 AM.
I head out at 8 AM
I heat up my lunch in a microwave
I work out every day
I warm up before exercising
I meet up with my friends at a cafe
I go out at 8:30 PM
I get in at 10 PM.
I tidy up my apartment
The police are urging drivers to avoid the area.
the increase in violence in our city centers

Meaning: leave someone in a tough situation
Example: He left me high and dry

Meaning: <사람∙사업 등> 을 방치하다, 돌보지 않다, ⋯을 소홀히 하다
Example: I’ve been neglecting my friends lately.
a bad / quick / short / violent temper, 고약한[성급한, 성마른, 난폭한] 성미
An icy wind was blowing. 얼음같이 차가운 바람이 불고 있었다

Word: regret to inform / say / announce that

Example: He insisted on going with me. 그는 나와 같이 가겠다고 고집했다
Who looks after the kids while you’re at work? 회사에 있는 동안 누가 아이들을 돌보나요?
get along with somebody ⋯와 잘 지내다, ⋯와 사이가 좋다
My patience was running out. 내 인내심은 한계를 보이고 있었다
It’s a shame you can’t come with us. 우리와 함께 갈수 없다니 아쉽구나.
Taking these precautions would cut down the risk of fires. 이런 예방조치들을 취하면 화재 위험이 줄어들 것이다
Samantha and Michael are getting married, but they haven’t yet broken the news to their parents.

Word: cost an arm and a leg
Example: A college education in America costs an arm and a leg.
Nicole paid top dollar for a shirt at Banana Republic.
Note: the highest end of a price range; a lot of money

Example: There was a strange man following me around the grocery store. He was giving me the creeps!
Note: to create a feeling of disgust or horror

Example: Someone must be lying. 누군가 거짓말을 하고 있는것이 분명하다.
My company lost $3 million last year. We might go belly-up.
We forgot to buy champagne for our New Year’s party, but Sonia brought some and really saved the day!
Note: to prevent a disaster or misfortune

Word: go back to the drawing board
Example: Frank’s new business failed, so he had to go back to the drawing board.
Note: to start again from the beginning

Example: He was given the ax two days before Christmas.
Jay scored 100% on his science test. He’s as sharp as a tack.
Dave and I spent hours talking over the details of the plan.
You shouldn’t be upset – after all, you asked him to leave. 속상해 할것 없어. 어쨌든 당신은 그에게 떠나달가고 했으니까.
There’s no point in worrying about things you can’t change.
Note: no reason to; it’s not worth (doing something)
to reach a decision; to decide

Example: We’ve run out of coffee, but at least we still have tea.
For many years, Barbara put up with her husband’s annoying behavior. Finally, she decided to leave him.
Diane realized that working as a cashier was a dead-end job.
Note: a job that won’t lead to anything else

Example: When Ted handed in his essay two weeks late, his teacher really lost her temper.
After Chris got canned, it took him a year to find a new job.
Note: to lose one’s job; to get fired

Example: When Jack Thompson retired as president of his company, his right-hand man took over.
Note: the most helpful assistant or employee

Example: Jill and Heather were friends, until Heather stabbed Jill in the back by stealing her boyfriend.
He felt betrayed by her.
Keep you chin up! You’ll find your lost dog soon.

Meaning: 해가 서쪽에서 뜨겠다야. 절대 일어날수 없는 일을 빗대서 하는 말.
Example: Will Ted teach Nicole how to play the guitar? When pigs fly!
When Ted showed up for chemistry class a half an hour late, his teacher really told him off.
Note: to scold; to tell someone in strong words what one really thinks

Example: Sue showed up twenty minutes late for class.

Meaning: (주로 나쁜 상황에서) 밝은 면을 보다, 긍정적으로 생각하다
Example: Leo was upset that his soccer game was canceled. His mother said, “Look on the bright side, now you can stay home and watch TV.”
Note: to be optimistic; to think about the positive part or aspect of a situation

Example: Ted was in love from the moment he set eyes on Amber.
Note: to look at; to see for the first time

Example: When Ted came home at 4 am. last Sunday, his mother said “Thank goodness you’re home! I was so worried about you.”
I know you’re four games behind, but you can still win the tennis match. Just hang in there!
Note: to persevere; to not give up

Meaning: 끈기 있게 노력하다, 불굴의 정신으로 계속하다

Example: Gary was out of work for a year before finding a new job.
Jenny was earning $5 an hour working at the store. She was really living from hand to mouth.
Note: to barely have enough money to survive

Example: You’ve been so stressed out lately. You really need to take a long vacation.

Meaning: 수지 균형을 맞추다, (수입 내에서) 생계를 꾸려나가다
Example: If you can’t make ends meet, you’ll need to start spending less.
Note: to manage one’s money so as to have enough to live on; to be okay financially

Example: I don’t like taking medicine. I’ll only take it as a last resort.
Note: if there are no other alternatives left; the last solution for getting out of a difficulty

Example: I know you’re running out of money. If worse comes to worst, you can always sell some of your jewelry.
Note: in the worst case; if absolutely necessary

Example: Ken and Sandra hope to sell their house for $3 million dollars. They always think big.
Moving into a new home is easier said than done
Brenda blew the interview and didn’t get the job offer.
Your aunt really spoils you.
The police were accused of botching the investigation.
Ted often cuts class to spend more time with his girlfriend
Note: to miss class without an excuse

Example: Amanda doesn’t get much done at the office. She’s too busy slacking off.
Ted partied all weekend. Finally, on Sunday night, he decided it was time to hit the books.
Nicole can’t stand broccoli. She simply refuses to eat it.

Tom likes to walk around town in his pajamas - he doesn’t give a hoot what people think.
The reason you’re late is beside the point. The fact is, your dinner is now cold.
Did you really have your heart set on going to Harvard?
Although the American figure skaters were good, they didn’t stand a chance of winning a gold medal at the Olympics.
Note: to have the possibility of success

Example: Professor Russo paid Jennifer a compliment. He said she had a beautiful smile.
Note: to give someone a compliment; to offer someone an admiring comment

Example: Being compared to my father is a great compliment.
I admire your honesty.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra is head an shoulders above any other orchestra in the area.
You won $2000 in the poetry writing contest? Way to go!
Do you like solving people’s problems? If so, you should consider going into psychology.
Note:
1. Enter. Go into the house and get a pen.
2. Enter another emotional state. Sally went into hysterics.
3. Discuss details. I don’t have time now to go into the whole story.

Example: Heather is really gung ho about her new job.
Don’t ask Mrs.Smith how old she is. It drives her crazy.
Sara is really rude. She always butts in to other people’s conversations.
It’s not your problem - don’t interfere.

Word: hit the nail on the head
Example: Steve hit the nail on the head with his idea of moving his company’s manufacturing facility to China.
When Daniel got promoted to vice president of the bank, his colleagues were green with envy.
Nicole kept telling Ted to turn down his stereo. Finally, he got angry and said, “Shut up!”
Note:
1. be quiet, stop speaking
EX: The professor talked for hours. I thought he’d never shut up.
2. Stop speaking

Example: During the storm, Billy was hiding under his kitchen table and was really shaking in his shoes.
Note: to tremble with fear; to be afraid

Example: Joey was on thin ice with his mom after he spent his lunch money on candy bars.
Note: to be in a dangerous position; to be temporarily on sombody’s bad side

Example: Polly hide behind the door, trembling with fear. 폴리는 공포에 떨며 문 뒤에 숨었다
Why are you so jealous of his success?
You adopted five children from a Romanian orphanage? You’ve got a heart of a gold!
Note: to be very kind and giving

Example: Nicole, stop pigging out on cookies or you’ll never be able to eat your dinner!
Note: to eat greedily; to stuff oneself

Example: Susan called her friend in the hospital to cheer her up.
I don’t like to see you in a bad mood. How can I cheer you up?
Whenever Susan feels on edge, she takes several deep breaths and starts to feel more relaxed.

Meaning: (문제 해결 등을 위해) (딱) 필요한 것, 바로 원하던 것
Example: Our trip to Florida was so relaxing. It was just what the doctor ordered!
You don’t need to wait for me to offer you something. Please just help yourself to whatever you want.
Mmmm, I love your chicken soup. It’s out of the world!
Jeff decided to go into business selling baseball cards.
Bob’s friend Charles made a bundle in the stock market and retired at age 45.
Note: to make a lot of money

Example: I’m glad you brought an umbrella - that was good thinking!
The scientist gave his assistant credit for the discovery.

Word: give credit where credit is due
Meaning: 어떤 사람의 공적이나 능력을 솔직하게 인정하거나 감사해야 한다는 뜻이다. 입은 비뚤어져도 말은 바로 하여야 한다..
Example: I will be sure to thank you when I give my speech. I always give credit where credit is due.
Note: to give thanks or acknowledgement to the person who deserves it

Example: Our flight to Berlin leaves at 7:00 a.m. tomorrow, so we’ll have to get up bright and early.
Ted was so nervous about his chemistry test that he didn’t sleep a wink the night before.
Larry became an investment banker after college, and now he works like a dong.

Meaning: '가능성이 희박함', '그럴리가 없다' 등의 뜻으로 아주 낮은 가능성을 나타내는 말
Example: The boy at school are always laughing at Dana. Will she be invited to the school dance? Fat chance!
Bob talks about working at McDonald’s, but the truth is he doesn’t have a clue about making hamburgers.
Yesterday, Joan’s son sat down with her for a couple of hours and gave her a crash course on using the Internet.
You’ve got a test tomorrow morning. Needless to say, you can’t stay out late tonight.
I have mixed feelings about the president of our company. He’s good with the clients, but he’s nasty to his employees.
Note: to feel positive about one aspect of something and negative about another

Example: He has a nasty temper. 그는 성격이 고약하다
When Linda’s passport was stolen in Florence, she was not a happy camper.
Note: a happy person; a satisfied participant

Example: I’ve never tried to make wine in my bathtub  before, but perhaps I’ll give it a shot.
Jeff loaned us his car for the weekend.
It was a tough break for us when Caroline quit. She was one of out top performers.
Note: When something unfortunate happens, it can be called a “tough break”

Example: If we have time before the movie, let’s drop by Bill’s house.
Note: to pay a short, often unannounced visit

Example: It might rain later, so our plans for the picnic are up in the air.
We had to hang around the airport for an extra six hours because our flight was delayed.
Note: to spend time idly; to linger

Example: It’s easy to feel down in the dumps when it’s raining outside
Note: to feel sad; to be depressed

Example: Amy is so crazy about golf, she’d like to play every day.
Don’t take this the wrong way, but I liked your hair better before you got it cut.

Meaning: ⋯이 좋아하는 것이 아니다, ⋯의 취미에 맞지 않다
Example: I know Joy is nice, but she’s simply not my cup of tea.
Note: the type of person or thing that one generally likes

Example: You lost your keys? Take it easy, I am sure you’ll find them.
Ted spent all of last summer hanging out by his friend’s pool

Meaning: 취향은 가지가지다, 사람마다 기호가 다른 법이다
Example: Ted likes to put sugar on his spaghetti. I guess there’s no accounting for taste.
Note: it’s impossible to explain individual likes and dislikes

Example: Last summer, Nicole had a blast backpacking through Europe with some friends.
Mike agreed to take out the garbage, saying under his breath, “I always do the dirty work around here.”
Kristen had three years of working for a large firm under her belt before leaving to start her own firm.
Note: to have or to get experience

Word: give someone a run for one’s money

Example: Some people think Tom Hanks is by far the best actor in America today.
Note: by a wide margin; by a great difference

Example: After Angela appeared on the cover of Vogue magazine, she was really full of herself.
Note: to think to much of oneself

Example: Jeremy loves to kid around, so don’t be offended by anything he says.

Meaning: (모욕적 발언 등으로) ⋯의 기분을 상하게 하다, ⋯을 불쾌하게 하다

Example: Our dinner guests are arriving in two hours. We’d better get down to business and start preparing.
Note: to get serious about a task

Word: give someone the time of day
Example: Sandra never gave me the time of day back in college, but now she calls me all the time for advise
Note: to ignore someone; to refuse to pay any attension to someone
to be cold to someone on purpose; to snub someone

Example: Samantha is a real goody-goody. She always offers to erase the blackboard at the end of class.
Lauren is such a brown-noser. She’s always telling her teacher how much she enjoys class.
Note: a person who’s constantly trying to win favor with people above them, such as teachers or bosses.

Word: you scratch my back and I’ll scratch yours
Example: I’ll help you with your homework if you do the dishes. You scratch my back and I’ll scratch yours.
Note: if you do me a favor, I’ll do you a favor; let’s cooperate

Example: You’ll make dinner every night for a month if I help you with your homework? Okay, it’s a deal!
If I can count on you to wake me up, I won’t set my alarm clock.
Note: to depend or reply on someone

Example: Don’t let him get under your skin.
I’ll be sure to make time for you when you visit me.
Note: to put time in one’s schedule for something

Example: Thanks for bringing the cookies, Don’t mention it

Meaning: 어떻게 지내니?, 잘 지내니? ((특히 친한 사이에서 쓰는 말))
Example: You never call me anymore. What’s up with that?
The house was in such bad shape, they decided to tear it down and re-build it from scratch.
Note: from the beginning; using all fresh ingredients rather than using a prepared mix

Meaning: (전적인 동의를 나타내며) 내 말이 바로 그 말이야, 정말 그래.
Example: You think our house needs repairs? You can say that again - even our toilet is broken!
I made a pig of myself by eating four slices of pie.
Note: to eat too much; to overeat

Example: I was just kidding when I said your new orange dress makes you look like a pumpkin.
Note: talking more to get a laugh than anything

Example: When Eminem appeared on stage, everybody went nuts.

Meaning: (하기 싫거나 힘든 일에 대해) 팔을 걷고 나서다, 착수하다
Example: You’d better roll up your sleeves and finish your homework.
Ted couldn’t figure out one of his math problems, so he asked his sister for help
The plumber estimated that it would cost $150 to fix our sink, but that was just a ballpark figure.
Nicole really jumped the gun by writing her acceptance speech before the results of the elections were announced.
Note: to start doing something too soon or ahead of everybody else

Example: Sit tight, the doctor will be with you in a few minutes.
I couldn’t resist taking a look in the box. 나는 상자 안을 들여다보지 않고는 견딜 수 없었다
How’s business, Mike? Can’t complain. I sold a lot of computers this month.
Note: Things are going well; I’m fine

Example: Scott loves to crunch numbers, so he decided to become an accountant.
My friend Emily wanted me to climb Mount McKinley with her, but I told her it was out of the question.
It would be worth your while to audition for the game show Jeopardy. You’d probably win a lot of money.
Note: worthy of one’s effort or time

Example: IBM offered to sweeten the deal by giving John a company car if he agreed to work for them.
Note: to make an offer more attractive

Example: May people laugh at him, but Bill actually makes a living selling gourmet dog food.
Note: to earn enough money to support oneself

Example: The highest salary we can offer you is $50,000 a year - take it or leave it
Note: accept or reject an offer, usually a final one

Example: You want to offer me free tickets to the J.Lo concert? Now you’re talking!
I wanted to pay less for the car, but the salesman drove a hard bargain.
Note: to be tough in negotiating an agreement; to negotiate something in one’s favor

Example: Let’s get the ball rolling on this project. We’ve only got one week to finish it.
Would you mind leading a hand in the garden? We need to finish planting these flowers before it starts raining.
At Nate’s high school, salsa dancing is all the rage this year.
Note: the latest fashion; popular right now

Meaning: 휴식하다. (take a rest는 보다 긴시간을 쉬는것)
Example: Let’s take a break from our work and go get some ice cream.
Note: to stop and rest from an activity

Example: After 11 hours of driving, I was getting tired. Fortunately, my friend offered to take over.
You’re in good hands with Tony. He’s excellent driver.
Steve has been an auto mechanic for 25 years. He really knows his stuff.
Note: to have an expertise in a field

Example: No wonder Liz is so overweight. She’s got such a sweet tooth!
I used to make delicious pies, but this one tastes terrible. I think I’ve lost my touch
Note: to no longer be able to something well

Example: I used to play tennis every day, but I haven’t played in years. I’m out of practice.
Note: no longer good at doing something

Example: Diana picked up some great new ideas at the workshop
Jim Paton will assume the role of finance director. 짐 패튼이 재무리사 역을 맡을 것이다
Elsa acquired a good knowledge of Chinese. 엘사는 중국어를 꽤 많이 익혔다
My new job will be easier once I learn some tricks of the trade.
Feel free to interrupt me and ask questions during my lecture.
Note: go ahead and do something; don’t hesitate (to do something)

Example: If you ‘are not planning on helping us prepare dinner, please get out of the way. The kitchen is crowded.
Note: to move out of the way; to stop interfering with someone’s plans or activities

Word: too many cooks spoil the broth
Example: You don’t need to help us. We have enough people helping already, and too many cooks spoil the broth
Note: too many people involved in an activity can ruin it

Example: We spent a few hours walking around downtown Chicago. It was so cold that we were ready to call it a night by nine o’clock.
Note: to stop an activity for the rest of the night

Example: Bob worked his tail off at the furniture store, but his boss fired him anyway.
Tony liked Tara immediately. It was love at first sight!
We’re just nuts about our new neighbors. We have them over for dinner once a month.
After dating her boyfriend Dan for four years, Erica finally decided to break up with him.
Note: to end a relationship with a romantic partner

Meaning: '적당히 좀 해!', '롱담하지 마시오!' 등의 뜻으로, 믿을 수 없거나 터무니없는 말에 대답하는 말
Example: You want me to pay $3 for one cookie? Give me a break!
We just bought a new printer at work. It can crank out 20 pages per minute.
Note: to produce rapidly or in a routine manner

Example: During the first years of their marriage, Brad and Jennifer were head over heels in love with each other.
May is crunch time for many students. It’s when they have their final exams.
Note: a short period when there’s high pressure to achieve a result.

Meaning: 머릿속에 한 가지 일밖에 없다, 오로지 한 가지 생각만 하다
Example: Ryan thinks about football all the time. He’s got a one-track mind.
Note: having all thoughts directed to just one thing or activity; focused on just one thing

Example: Don’t give up on chemistry class. If you keep plugging away, you will eventually learn the material.
Note: to proceed with a boring or routine task; to keep trying

Example: We have more than enough food for dinner. Go ahead and invite your friend to join us.
Note: to continue; to proceed without hesitation

Example: I feel sorry for Jeffrey. The kids at school are very nasty to him. They really treat him like dirt.
Note: to behave in a nasty way towards somebody; to treat someone poorly

Example: Ted and Amber started making out at the stoplight and didn’t realize that the light had turned green.
I’ve got a 20-page paper due tomorrow morning, and I haven’t even started writing it yet. I guess I’ll be pulling an all-nighter!
Note: to stay up all night to do work

Example: No wonder you’re cold - It’s January and you’re walking around outside without a coat!
After working 12-hour day and then coming home and cooking dinner for her family, Tanya felt like a basket case.
Note: someone or something in a useless or hopeless condition

Example: Finishing her English essay was a load off Nicole’s mind.
Whenever Nicole rides on the back of her friend’s motorcycle, Susan is a nervous wreck.

Meaning: (경험에 근거한) 통상적인 원칙, 통상적으로 말할 수 있는 바
Example: When cooking fish, a good rule of thumb is 10 minutes in the oven for each inch of thickness.
According to conventional wisdom, a diet high in salt can cause high blood pressure.
Juan changed the light bulb and said “That should do the trick!”
Ted thinks it’ll be easy to become a rock star. In reality, it will take years of hard work.
I used to be friends with Monica, but she gossiped all the time and it really turned me off
Note: to cause to feel dislike or revulsion

Meaning: (남의 사생활∙소문 등에 대해) 입방아를 찧다, 뒤소리하다

Example: Jenny has such a big head. No wonder nobody wants to be friends with her!
Did you enjoy the Madonna concert? I’ll say!
There is compelling evidence that she murdered her husband. 그녀가 남편을 살해했다는 유력한 증거가 있다
